title: First steps with the Package jmleIRT
text: Key features: - Missing values design allowed (NA). - Optional epsilon adjustment (eps) reduce estimation bias extreme scores. - Centering based either “items” “persons” ensure identifiability. - Post-hoc bias correction (bias_correction = TRUE/FALSE). - Optional computation Warm’s weighted likelihood estimates (WLE) person parameters (estimatewle = TRUE). - Fast Newton-Raphson optimization C++.

title: Joint Maximum Likelihood Estimation of the Rasch Model
code: library(jmleIRT)  # Simulate response  40 persons (p) × 5 items (i) set.seed(123) X <- matrix(rbinom(40 * 5, 1, 0.5), nrow = 40)  # Estimate Rasch model using JMLE with bias correction fit <- jmle_estimation(X, max_iter = 200, conv = 1e-5,                       center = "items", bias_correction = TRUE)  # Item difficulties (centered) print(fit$beta)  # Compute Weighted Likelihood Estimates for persons wle_res <- estimate_wle(X, fit$beta)  # Person ability estimates via WLE print(wle_res$wle)

title: Joint Maximum Likelihood Estimation of the Rasch Model
text: Rasch model fundamental Item Response Theory (IRT) model used dichotomous item data. probability person pp ability θp\theta_p answers item ii difficulty βi\beta_i correctly modeled : P(Xpi=1∣θp,βi)=eθp−βi1+eθp−βiP(X_{pi} = 1 \mid \theta_p, \beta_i) = \frac{e^{\theta_p - \beta_i}}{1 + e^{\theta_p - \beta_i}} Xpi∈{0,1}X_{pi} \\{0,1\} indicates correctness response.

title: Joint Maximum Likelihood Estimation of the Rasch Model
text: JMLE simultaneously estimates person abilities θ=(θ1,…,θP)\theta = (\theta_1, \ldots, \theta_P) item difficulties β=(β1,…,βI)\beta = (\beta_1, \ldots, \beta_I) maximizing joint likelihood observed responses: L(θ,β)=∏p=1P∏=1IP(Xpi∣θp,βi)L(\theta, \beta) = \prod_{p=1}^P \prod_{=1}^P(X_{pi} \mid \theta_p, \beta_i) typically solved via iterative algorithm updating θp\theta_p βi\beta_i, convergence criteria met. Although easy implement computationally efficient, JMLE estimates suffer bias, especially small samples extreme response patterns.

title: Joint Maximum Likelihood Estimation of the Rasch Model
text: Joint Maximum Likelihood Estimation (JMLE) Rasch model known produce biased parameter estimates, especially finite samples extreme response patterns. jmleIRT package implements two key bias correction techniques: Epsilon adjustment: Proposed Bertoli Barsotti, Punzo, Lando, method adds small positive constant ε>0\varepsilon > 0 estimation process. adjustment prevents infinite log-odds perfect zero scores, ensuring finite item difficulty ability estimates. also helps alleviate bias related extreme response patterns smoothing estimation. Analytical bias correction: approach involves modifying item difficulty estimates based theoretical bias expressions derived asymptotic expansions minimum divergence estimators. aims reduce structural bias inherent JMLE estimates described psychometric literature (e.g., Bertoli Barsotti & Punzo, 2012; Lando & Bertoli Barsotti, 2014). combination, epsilon adjustment promotes numerical stability improved bias behavior estimation level, analytical bias correction provides targeted, theoretically grounded refinement item parameter estimates enhance overall accuracy robustness JMLE algorithm.

title: Analytical First-Order Bias Correction for Joint Maximum Likelihood Estimators in the Rasch Model — biasCorrection
text: JML estimators well-known suffer incidental parameter bias number items (\(\)) finite, resulting biased parameter estimates. bias generally order \(1/\). bias correction implemented follows first-order analytic correction approach, approximates bias term \(B\) parameter : $$ \hat{\theta}^{corr} = \hat{\theta} - \frac{1}{} \hat{B}_{\theta}, \quad \hat{\beta}^{corr} = \hat{\beta} - \frac{1}{} \hat{B}_{\beta} $$ \(\hat{B}\) estimated based observed scores \(u_i\) expected Fisher information \(v_i\), calculated $$ \hat{B}_i \approx \frac{E[v_i u_i]}{E[v_i^2]}. $$ implementation, scores information calculated based logistic form Rasch model, \(p_{ni} = \frac{e^{\theta_n - \beta_i}}{1 + e^{\theta_n - \beta_i}}\) probability person \(n\) correctly answers item \(\). Missing responses (NA) data matrix \(X\) handled omitting entries. bias correction inspired incidental parameters literature (Neyman & Scott, 1948; Lancaster, 2000; Arellano & Hahn, 2006), shows Maximum Likelihood estimators models many nuisance parameters (like person parameters Rasch) biased number observations per parameter limited. function applies computationally efficient closed-form bias correction using first second derivatives log-likelihood Rasch model likelihood function, evaluated JML estimates. estimator reduces bias estimating expected score information terms: $$ u_{ni} = X_{ni} - p_{ni}, \quad v_{ni} = p_{ni} (1 - p_{ni}) $$ person \(n\) item \(\), aggregating across items persons. bias terms person \(n\) item \(\) estimated : $$ \hat{B}_{\theta,n} = \frac{\sum_i v_{ni} u_{ni}}{\sum_i v_{ni}^2}, \quad \hat{B}_{\beta,} = \frac{\sum_n v_{ni} (p_{ni} - X_{ni})}{\sum_n v_{ni}^2} $$ method applicable number items \(\) fixed moderate, number persons \(N\) large.

Journal Econometrics, 95(2), 391-413. - Arellano, M., & Hahn, J. (2006). Understanding Bias Nonlinear Panel Models. Review Economic Studies, 73(2), 557-578.

text: Fits Rasch (1PL) model using joint maximum likelihood via efficient C++ Newton-Raphson implementation. Missing responses (NA) allowed. Optionally returns Warm's WLE person estimates computed estimated item difficulties.
